TipQuick checklist (Gradescope)




Submit one PDF (clear scans, high contrast).
Start each question on a new page (recommended).
Use Gradescope‚Äôs tool to map pages ‚Üí questions.
If the grader cannot read it, they may request a resubmission or deduct points.
For multi-page answers, link all relevant pages to that question.



Need help submitting? See Gradescope‚Äôs student guide: How to submit variable-length assignments

title: Homework
text:
Policies






WarningLate days



You have 6 late days total, with a maximum of 2 late days per assignment.
Each late day is a 24-hour extension (e.g., Wed 11:59 PM ‚Üí Thu 11:59 PM = 1 late day).
No credit is given after 48 hours past the deadline, or after late days are exhausted.




Collaboration policy and honor code
Students must work individually on all homework assignments.
You may have high-level discussions with classmates, but anything you submit must be your own work.
You may reuse small snippets of publicly available code (e.g., StackOverflow) only if properly attributed.


Generative AI tools policy
In this course, every element of class assignments must be fully prepared by the student.
The use of generative AI tools for any part of your work is not allowed and will be treated as plagiarism ‚Äî unless it is explicitly permitted and announced by the instructor.


Regrade policy
Regrade requests are submitted through Gradescope. Include a clear explanation of the grading error.

Deadline: within 1 week of receiving your grade, by 11:59 PM.
We may regrade the entire assignment (your score may go up or down).

Legitimate requests - Points were added incorrectly. - The answer exists but was on a different page. - The grader claims a specific case fails, but your implementation works for that case.
Illegitimate requests - Disagreeing with the rubric / asking for more partial credit without an error. - ‚ÄúMy solution wasn‚Äôt clear, but what I meant was correct.‚Äù

Collaboration Policy
You are encouraged to discuss problem sets with classmates, but you must write up your own solutions. Copying code or derivations is not allowed.


Resources

Textbook (Main): R Dorf and R Bishop, Modern Control System, Prentice-Hall, 13th Edition, 2017
Textbook (optional): Franklin, Powell, Emami-Naeini, Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, (8th Ed).
Software: We will use Matlab/Simulink for computational assignments and and Python in some cases.

title: EE380: Control Systems
text:
Announcements


Week 2 ‚Äî HW1 is posted
Please check the Homework page for HW1 details and the due date/time.




Week 1 ‚Äî Getting started
Welcome to the course! Please review the Syllabus and install MATLAB/Simulink.
Python is optional unless you want to run local simulations.

title: Instructor Guide: EE380 Course Website
text:
This website is built with Quarto. It uses GitHub Pages for hosting and Pyodide for interactive Python simulations.





Create a new repository on GitHub (e.g., ee380-website).
Clone this folder to your machine.
Push this initial code to the main branch.





Install Quarto: Download from quarto.org.
VS Code: Recommended editor. Install the ‚ÄúQuarto‚Äù extension.
Install Pyodide Extension: Open a terminal in this folder and run: bash     quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive     # OR for standard pyodide     quarto add coatless-quarto/pyodide (Note: The current template assumes standard code blocks initially. To use the interactive features, you must install the extension.)








Open calendar.qmd.
Add new rows to the table for the upcoming week.
Link slides (put PDF files in a slides/ folder if you like, or link externally).





Open homework.qmd.
Add a new row to the table.
Link the PDF assignment.




To publish, you just need to push to GitHub. The Setup is already configured (see .github/workflows/publish.yml).
git add .
git commit -m "Update week 3 schedule"
git push
Within nearly 60 seconds, your site at https://<username>.github.io/<repo> will update.




Once the Pyodide extension is installed, you can add interactive cells like this:
```{pyodide-python}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
plt.plot(x, np.sin(x))
plt.show()
```
This will render as an interactive, editable, regular Python cell in the student‚Äôs browser.
